filpkart.comment: My previous three smartphones have all been HTC Android devices. I decided to try the Moto G (2gen) after seeing Moto G and Moto X with friends. I had the following requirements: * Android Lollipop * Sufficient internal storage to let me install lots of apps (my previous phone had just 4 GB, which was not enough) * dual SIM I also wanted a phone, not a phablet. I would be very reluctant to go for a 5.5" screen, for instance. The Moto G is great. Call quality, data connectivity, wifi reliability, are all very good. (My last phone, the HTC Desire 600, used to drop wifi randomly and repeatedly.) The 16 GB internal storage gives me more than 12 GB free after system software and bundled apps. This is more than enough for lots of apps. Unlike the 1gen device, this one has a MicroSD slot, which allows for a lot of the apps and data to be moved to the SD card. I don't get any HTC enhancements to the UI -- I get just stock Lollipop here. But I am finding it quite usable. Some things don't work as expected, but they are Lollipop problems. I should not dwell on them in a phone review. I also bought a Motorola flip cover for the phone, which replaces the back cover and fits on the body very well. I love this cover, because opening the flip-top switches on the screen without me having to hit the power button. Very nice touch. (I used to keep switching on the screen just to check the time, since my cellphone has been my watch for the last few years.) I will highly recommend this accessory. Have not used the supplied headset, so I can't comment on its quality. I have used the headset output with my Etymotic HF2 and ER4-PT IEMs and the sound quality is excellent -- it's all you can expect without a dedicated headphone amp. Adequate volume too. The Bluetooth pairing with my Plantronics Voyager Legend is very solid -- I don't find Bluetooth pairing drop-outs as I used to find occasionally with my HTC. I have done upto two hour-long tele-conferences using GoToMeeting and Skype using this phone and my Voyager Legend, with the phone online on 3G. It works well. Am not a gamer, so I can't comment on game performance. I find it hard to justify the price of an expensive HTC 826 after experiencing this phone.

filpkart.comment: Hello there, I'm a 17 year old boy who bought this phone recently and so this is my honest review for this phone. There are many pros for this phone which you might've already seen in other reviews, so I'm gonna list some important cons about this phone.. . . 1). Battery - Honestly, this is the worst battery backup I've seen on any phone till date. But so they totally depend on one's usage. If you play some heavy games and play some music then browse for about an hour and then check Youtube you might get disappointed as you might've to charge it twice a day! But the same phone if my father uses he gets around 60% backup remaining after a full day usage. His usage is like, he frequently make or attend calls then if got some free time checks WhatsApp or Facebook, this is his full day usage! So, it might be or might not be a deal breaker for some. . . 2). Charger - Again, the battery takes too much time to charge with its default charger. It takes around 7-8 hours for me to charge it from 15% to 100% as the output is only 0.5 Amp. But if you change your charger having an Output of 1 Amp. then it'll charge in approximately 1 hour 30 minutes. But don't risk your phone by buying some Chinese charger, do buy some branded charger. And yes the charger does not have a detachable cable which could work as a Micro-USB cable for your PC. So, buy separately a Micro-USB cable. . . 3). Lollipop - This is not the problem with phone but with its Software. The UI is slightly sluggish. It does'nt mean it hangs a lot, you'll rarely see some lag on it. The latest update by Google which is installed on this phone is Lollipop v5.0.2. Users who bought this phone with Kitkat said the phone was buttery smooth before installing the Lollipop update. Even the issue with Battery Backup is because of Lollipop as Google officially said it and so Google released Lollipop 5.1 which have many improvements including battery backup. Motorola has confirmed the Lollipop 5.1 update for Moto G (2nd Generation) and other Moto phones but there is no official wording on release date. . . These are some important cons about this phone worth to be mentioned. But don't forget there are many pros as well which might be pleasing for many, like me! If you think that these cons are deal breaker for you then I'll suggest you to go for ASUS Zenfone 2 and if you don't have any problem with chinese brands, then do check Xiaomi Mi4i. Again they've their own cons so choose wisely!

filpkart.comment: NOTE: In any case, if u feel exhausted by the length, My sincere advice: Don't read, not even partially. Doing so can result in unintended perceptions. It's written to be read fully as a whole. If u want to leave, do it right now. CAUTION: The review would begin with discouraging buyers, but there's a lot of good news down under. Don't miss that, it's going to help u a lot. Therefore, read the full review, else don't read at all. First of all, everyone who intends to view this review for advice on whether he/she should buy it, NO, Not at all. Check the date and time of this review. Guys, its June 2015. The processor used in this phone dates back to the Moto G (1st gen). 1GB RAM, while it was enough a year ago, its not the case now as the apps are getting more resource intensive. In simple words, they need more RAM. So what should u do. Go for other phones? NO. Other phones, such as Mi4i, have a lot of software issues. For example, MIUI (Xiaomi's OS) alone consumes 800 MB RAM. And it's not so fast either, even with 2 gb ram. I mean seriously, you dont want to shell out Rs 13000 to go for a phone whose RAM management is so poor. MIUI, for all its customisation, is a bug magnet and cause a lot of overheating issues with a phone. So every time there's a breakout (which is often), company issues a statement saying they will release an update. In all the developing course, It's the user that suffers. Seriously, U don't want to risk ur hard earned money and user experience on a smartphone whose quality is limited to regular updates (NOTE: regular update size is close to 800MB). On the contrary, stock android consumes just 450 MB ram and its ram management is excellent and safer. It is pure, simple, elegant and minimalist. You guys might be thinking that mine is a probably hate case against MIUI or Xiaomi. In reality, it's on the contrary. The reason i'm only talking about MIUI is because it's still the best of custom UI's, others are far worse. Anyways, it's time for good news. Moto G 2015, (yes u heard what u saw), the 3rd generation of Motorola's most loved smartphone is surely coming by the end of july, probably earlier. It's going to be the most awesome phone in the budget. It will boast stock android, faster processor, 1080p screen resolution, 2GB RAM, 8 and 16 gigs internal memory models, and will retain one deal maker that's missing on mi4i, Expandable Memory Slot (upto 32 or 64 gigs). You might think that these are rumours. But its logical, isn't it. Otherwise, how do u expect motorola to survive in a world where 2 gigs RAM is quickly becoming the norm. You can also google it to confirm that it's coming. Lastly, it won't be fitting if i don't express my gratitute to this amazing device. I bought the device in feburary 2015. It's best on quality, user experience is the most excellent thing. Hardware is impressive. Designed to hold comfortably in hands. It does not lag. Battery backup lasts for a full working day (not more). Many of you might be thinking that I'm not a power user or I don't play games, Well, u're right. But that's what u expect from a phone this range. I won't claim it's a flagship by any means. It's a mid range device, but a perfect mid ranger. The reason I've reviewed this device so late is because I wanted to gift a 5-inch smartphone to my mother on her birthday, which is in june. So I saw a hell lot of reviews of smartphones under rs.15000 like Asus Zenfone 2, Zenfone 5, Mi4i, Redmi 2, MeiZu mi note, Yu Yuphoria, Yureka, Lenovo a6000 plus on a hell lot of you tube channels like GeekyRanjit, C4ETech, Bailey Stien, Intellect Digest, Android Authority, Techniqued, u name it. In the process, I wasted almost 3 days watching videos, reviews, typing constantly before settling for Mi4i. But it's overheating issues and its dependence on large updates for quality coupled with unexpendable 16gb storage (out of which u hardly get 10gigs) constantly flogged my mind. Then suddenly I saw my moto g (2014), and thought: why not this? I nearly ordered it, just noticing seconds before that most of the phones were shipping with 2 gigs, even when they were priced lower. I thought probably that was because of custom UI's (which is partially true), but I also found out that apps were starting to use more RAM than ever, So I backed out. Though my moto g still provides me with 450mb free ram (which is just enough), but when u think of a year later in 2016, 1gb becomes pointless. A budget buyer usually buys a phone that can serve him best value for at least 1.5 years. And don't forget a 2 year old processor. So DEFINITELY NOT. Again guys, I know it's long but it would rather spare u the 4 day headache (in my case, I had a very fast internet, 30gb plan and did all this on a laptop. For mobile users, it can take forever). So I'm not at all sorry for the length. I coudn't have described it any lesser and better. Hope, It would help most of u guys.

filpkart.comment: After reading a lot of reviews and watching unboxing videos I bought this phone. So I had a fair idea what to expect. But it wasn't what I expected. First, I received the phone in Moto G branded box without any plastic encasing it. So it seemed to be that I have been delivered an unpacked product. Second the box contained only the phone. By only phone I mean only phone (and couple of manuals). The charger and earphone were included separately outside the Moto G box. Third the charger is not branded by Motorola and it does not have any USB cable. The earphones are Motorola branded but are probably the worst quality earphones (in terms of materials used, not sound wise) I have ever seen. In unboxing videos of Moto G I could see that the charger and earphones were included in the Moto G box itself, but this wasn't the case with me. This arouses a lot of suspicion in my mind – has Flipkart cheated me out with this product. In Flipkart’s defense the actual Moto G phone is working pretty well and I couldn’t find any signs that I was delivered an unpacked product. But the unbranded charger and low quality phone makes me wonder if Flipkart is taking its customers for a ride.
